column1: Data Supplied By: National Livestock Reporting Service
Data source: National Livestock Reporting Service
Please see terms of use here: https://www.mla.com.au/general/Terms-and-conditions/data-and-information/

Cattle numbers jumped to 780 yarded, quality was mostly plainer secondary types lacking shape and finish, however there was a nice run of very well presented heavy cows. Most of the usual buying group attended in a softer market across all categories. Young cattle were back 20c to 30c, grown steers dropped 20c and grown heifer were 15c to 30c/kg softer. Heavy cows sold to 25c cheaper, and the medium and light weights slipped to 10c to 15c/kg. Heavy bulls sold 5c cheaper and the lighter and young bulls sold 30c/kg softer with quality a factor.
 
Young cattle sold to the trade from 254c to 310c for the better quality and the plainer types made from 212c to 266c/kg. Feeders and restockers paid 150c to 264c for the secondary types and 220c to 314c/kg for the better bred cattle. Grown Steers made from 270c to 322c, grown heifers sold to the trade from 258c to 298c and restockers paid 168c to 270c/kg. Manufacturing Beef steers made from 210c to 268c and the dairy portion made from 126c to 260c/kg.
 
Heavy cows sold from 230c to 290c/kg. Medium weight cows made from 180c to 250c and the light weighs sold from 100c to 200c/kg. Dairy cows sold from 120c to 228c/kg.  Heavy bulls made from 285c to 323c, the lighter and younger bulls made from 208c to 248c/kg.
 
Market Reporter, Sheona Lamb
